jx.jx_en_mean: (informal)spend a considerable time drinking in a public house
provide support or assistance for someone or something that would otherwise fail or decline

lj.lj_ly: the government spent £3 billion in an attempt to prop up the pound.
lj.lj_ls: 政府用30亿英镑支撑英镑。

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: probably from Middle Dutch proppe 'support (for vines')

entry.def: If you prop an object on or against something, you support it by putting something underneath it or by resting it somewhere.

example.ex: He rocked back in the chair and propped his feet on the desk...
example.tran: 他往椅背上一靠，把脚搭在桌子上。

example.ex: He propped his bike against the bus.
example.tran: 他把自行车靠在公共汽车上。

entry.def: A prop is a stick or other object that you use to support something.
To be a prop for a system, institution, or person means to be the main thing that keeps them strong or helps them survive.

example.ex: The army is one of the main props of the government...
example.tran: 军队是政府的主要后盾之一。

example.ex: I had two props in my life; one was alcohol, the other work.
example.tran: 我生命中有两大支柱：一个是酒，另一个是工作。

entry.def: The props in a play or film are all the objects or pieces of furniture that are used in it.

example.ex: ...the backdrop and props for a stage show.
example.tran: 一场舞台剧的背景幕和道具

entry.tran: （橄榄球争球时的）第一排边锋
entry.def: In rugby, a prop or prop forward is one of the two players who position themselves in the front row when a group called a scrum is formed.
A prop is the same as a propeller .

means.word_mean: 1. a support placed beneath or against something to keep it from shaking or falling
2. any movable articles or objects used on the set of a play or movie;

sentences.sentence: "before every scene he ran down his checklist of props"

means.word_mean: 3. a propeller that rotates to push against air
1. support by placing against something solid or rigid;
